repnme.cdata!:
Argentina - Native Forests and Protected
            Areas Project; Argentina - Biodiversity Conservation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Native Forests and
            Protected Areas (NFPA) Project for Argentina were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was negligible to low, Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and borrower performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Ratings for the Biodiversity
            Conservation Project (ABC) for Argentina were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, risk to development outcome was
            moderate, Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and
            borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: The Bank should encourage natural resource project
            managers to take advantage of rapidly changing advances in
            biodiversity conservation methods and tools to complement
            traditional on-the-ground monitoring of indicator species
            surveys. These include satellite imagery and aerial
            photographs of habitat vegetation cover, or real-time remote
            monitoring devices and camera traps when conservation of
            specific species is the objective. Blending different
            lending instruments, such as International Bank of
            Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) loans with Global
            Environment Facility (GEF) grants, to achieve different
            natural resource management objectives can be an effective
            way to engage clients in addressing the full range of sector
            challenges they face. For example, the decision to use an
            IBRD loan to help Argentina increase park system revenues
            under the NFPA Project while preserving ecoregions of global
            significance under the ABC Project justified the use of a
            GEF grant. When experimenting with new techniques or
            approaches to land-use practices or natural resource
            management, it is best to approach experimental
            interventions in a measured way assuming that unexpected
            difficulties, costs, and delays will inevitably arise. The
            NFPA Project conducted applied research projects on
            compatible land-use practices in productive landscapes while
            the ABC Project introduced alternative, less destructive
            productive activities in park buffer zones.

14499107.trustfund:
BBFAO-BB FAO,BBGEF-BB GLOBAL ENVIRONMENTAL FUND,TF028372-GEF1 - BIODIVERSITY
            CONSERVATION PROJECT,TF028464-GEF1 PDF B: BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Biodiversity
            Conservation Project for Argentina were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was low
            or negligible, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and
            the Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: development is not a linear process, and
            processes need to be sufficiently flexible to adapt to
            changes on the ground. Although the project experienced some
            setbacks, including delays and difficulties during
            implementation, it managed to produce highly relevant
            impacts for the protected area sector by closing. The Bank,
            as an institution, should ensure that its instruments,
            philosophy and approaches to development are flexible enough
            to adapt to the changing country conditions, while
            maintaining focus on the project development objective. The
            creation of a protected area is a complex process that
            involves diverse actors and requires substantial
            coordination. In future projects, sufficient time should be
            allocated according to the complexity of participatory
            processed and taking into account the number of actors and
            decision makers involved. This is especially important in
            situations where a diverse spectrum of stakeholders are
            concerned (private land holders, intermediary agents,
            stakeholders, federal, and provincial governments).
            Participation is critical at all levels, yet it is time
            consuming and the outcomes are unpredictable.

5084068.trustfund:
TF032417-ARGENTINA - PROTECTED
            AREAS;NATIVE FORESTS,TF028464-GEF1 PDF B: BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION,TF028372-GEF1 - BIODIVERSITY
            CONSERVATION PROJECT,TF034304-ARGENTINA - BIODIVERSITY
            CONSERVATION PROTECTION PROJECT
5084068.majtheme: Social dev/gender/inclusion,Environment and natural resource management

abstracts.cdata!:
The Biodiversity Conservation Project
            conserves globally important biodiversity in Argentina by a)
            expanding and diversifying the existing National Protected
            Areas System, and b) sustaining their management by
            institutional strengthening, public consultation and
            participation, and improving information management. As
            such, the project comprises 3 components: protected areas
            (PA); information management; and management, monitoring,
            and evaluation. The Protected Areas component consists of
            three sub-components: a) establishing and consolidating new
            PAs; b) sustainable development activities in PA buffer
            zones; and c) activities to enhance public participation in
            park planning and management. Under these 3 sub-components,
            (1) national parks are built at five national PAs in poorly
            represented ecosystems; and technical assistance, limited
            equipment, and small works are provided; (2) improved
            community land use practices are supported through pilot
            projects, extension activities, and public awareness
            activities; and (3) a participation plan and a mitigation
            plan are implemented to encourage broad support and to
            alleviate social costs. The Biodiversity Information
            Management component puts in place an internet-based network
            that provides training and needed standards, finances system
            development, acquires hardware, and reconfigures existing
            databases. The Management, Monitoring, and Evaluation
            component finances technical assistance, equipment, and
            operational costs.
